headline.main: Detective Work and Science Reveal a New Lethal Bacteria

docs.abstract: Last article in series, Fresh Hazards, examines scientific detective work that led to discovery of new, deadly strain of E coli bacteria that is infiltrating US food supply, turning up in some of most notorious food poisoning episodes in recent history; scientists studying outbreaks in Oregon in 1981 and Michigan in 1982 say new strain was likely spawned by E coli bacterium, which normally lives innocuously in intestines of people and animals, during dysentery epidemic in Central America in 1970's; believe virus, which invades cells like bacteria to reproduce, somehow carried toxin-producing gene from Shigella, bacteria that was causing epidemic, over to E coli; new strain can cause diseases from standard diarrhea to kidney failure and death; once individual is infected, there is no effective medical treatment to combat it; despite discovery 16 years ago, it still continues to befuddle doctors, who often misdiagnose its infections; photos; diagrams (L)
docs.lead_paragraph: People in the United States are sickened by their food once a year, on average. But the food poisoning that suddenly appeared in White City, Ore., in December 1981 was something else. It was terrifying, and dramatic, and it seemed to have no cause. In the end, however, that mini-epidemic turned out to be the first show of force by a new strain of bacteria that is now infesting the food supply, infecting as many as 20,000 Americans a year and killing 500.
